values in records should not be escaped.
This lead to structs (and other non-literals in AST) being returned
as AST, which was unexpected and incorrect.

Before:

```elixir
defmodule Struct do
  defstruct foo: nil
end
defmodule Test do
  import Record
  defrecord :bar, data: %Struct{}
end

iex> require Test
iex> Test.bar(Test.bar())
[data: {:%{}, [], [__struct__: Struct, foo: nil]}]
```

After:

```elixir
iex> require Test
iex> Test.bar(Test.bar())
[data: %Struct{foo: nil}]
```"},{"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/elixir-lang/elixir/issues/5020","repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/elixir-lang/elixir","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/elixir-lang/elixir/issues/5020/labels{/name}","comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/elixir-lang/elixir/issues/5020/comments","events_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/elixir-lang/elixir/issues/5020/events","html_url":"https://github.com/elixir-lang/elixir/pull/5020","id":165951882,"number":5020,"title":"Fix have been rewritten changing the approach.
Previous approach was based on count (now named "n") number of elements to be fetched,
and slice/2 would call slice/3.
This leads to the problem of having to recalculate the amount of elements in the enumerable
when dealing with negative indexes.
The new aproach uses slice/2 as the main funtion, and deal with start and finish indexes.
When a negative index is needed, we determine the number of elements, and we convert it to indexes.

Benchmarks for the new implemetation can be seen here:

Runing time: https://gist.github.com/eksperimental/e7cda7722d42e43c4c2f69825149c7df#file-enum_slice_benchmarking_report_new-txt-L773

Comparison: compiling over a FS that has slow `open()`, `stat()` and company, builds are painfully slow. This affects builds over NFS and `vboxsf` (VirtualBox, often under Vagrant).

An initial rookie diagnosis: stracing the build (with `-e trace=file`) shows each directory and file path is hit many times with `open()`, `openat()`, `stat()`, etc. A quick read of `lib/compilers/elixir.ex` and `mix/utils.ex` leads me to suspect initially of `Mix.Utils.extract_*`. The logic flow leads to many queries to the OS about the same file path.

as errors causes more harm than good when it's enabled for dependencies. We should disable it for both the elixir and erlang compilers.

Elixir adheres to version 8.0 of the Unicode standard.

### Expected behavior

Elixir adheres to version 9.0 of the Unicode standard.

reported an interesting dialyzer error from ecto:
```
The call 'Elixir.Ecto.Queryable':to_query('Elixir.Ecto.Query':t()) 
contains an opaque term as 1st argument when a structured term of type 
atom() | bitstring() | fun() | pid() | port() | reference() | maybe_improper_list() | number() | tuple() | map() 
is expected
```

And it makes sense, because protocol is defined externally to the module with opaque type and relies on the internal structure for dispatch.
On the other hand often the protocol implementations are conceptually part of the module that defines the type.

@fishcakez proposed to define `@dialyer :no_opaque` in `defprotocol`

got Elixir v1.2.6 running on OS X.

Here's a test project in which you can reproduce the issue – https://github.com/alco/mixdepstest.

Clone the project and edit the Ecto dep `mix.exs` to look like this:

```elixir
{:ecto, "2.0.0-rc.6"},
```

Then run `mix deps.get`. Here's the result I get:

```
$ mix deps.get
Running dependency resolution
Dependency resolution completed
  connection: 1.0.2
  db_connection: 1.0.0-rc.1
  decimal: 1.1.2
  ecto: 2.0.0-rc.6
  poolboy: 1.5.1
  postgrex: 0.11.2
* Updating ecto (Hex package)
  Checking package (https://repo.hex.pm/tarballs/ecto-2.0.0-rc.6.tar)
  Using locally cached package
* Updating postgrex (Hex package)
  Checking package (https://repo.hex.pm/tarballs/postgrex-0.11.2.tar)
  Using locally cached package
* Updating db_connection (Hex package)
  Checking package (https://repo.hex.pm/tarballs/db_connection-1.0.0-rc.1.tar)
  Using locally cached package
Dependencies have diverged:
* postgrex (Hex package)
  the dependency postgrex

  > In mix.exs:
    {:postgrex, "> 0.0.0", [hex: :postgrex, manager: :mix]}

  does not match the requirement specified

  > In deps/ecto/mix.exs:
    {:postgrex, "~> 0.11.2", [hex: :postgrex, optional: true]}

  Ensure they match or specify one of the above in your deps and set "override: true"
** (Mix) Can't continue due to errors on dependencies
```

Without making any other changes I run `mix deps.get` again and it works this time around:

```
$ mix deps.get
Running dependency resolution
All dependencies up to date
```

That is why I think it's a bug, because the error only happens in the first invocation of `mix deps.get`.

You can see the resulting `mix.lock` that I got in [this commit](https://github.com/alco/mixdepstest/commit/71a2c1c22e2ecfa963e4922c7f4920bcdb4a8647) in the test This is something that would have saved me personally a lot of time.
For function headers, wouldn't it be extremely useful if the compiler/parser suggested the intended pattern that the code was trying to match when raising a `FunctionClauseError`?

For example, I wrote the following function:
`def render("template.json", %{group: group})`

I believed (wrongly) that the second argument was going to be %{group: some_group_variable}.
Especially that I did have other related functions that worked fine with this pattern.
I kept getting a FunctionClauseError and I didn't know why (my fault eventually, of course).

Second scenario, I misspelled an argument in a pattern. The function was (phoenix):
`def video_path(conn, :update, ...)`

And I called:
`video_path(conn, :udpate, ...)`

I went crazy here. I saw the typo in its correct form until I caught it after a few hours after I had some "away" time.


I think it would be very valuable to do something like:
```
** (FunctionClauseError) no function clause matching in Rumbl.Router.Helpers.video_path/4
** Provided pattern: video_path(conn, :udpate)
** Valid patterns:
        video_path(&1, :index)
        video_path(&1, :update)
        video_path(&1, :delete)
```
Or something similar to recently came across an exception when I tried to name a GenServer using a string. The same will happen for GenEvent, Supervisor, Agent etc.

```elixir
iex(1)> pid = GenEvent.start_link(name: "this is a test")
** (CaseClauseError) no case clause matching: "this is a test"
    (elixir) lib/gen_event.ex:375: GenEvent.do_start/2
iex(1)> pid = GenEvent.start_link(name: :this_is_a_test)
{:ok, #PID<0.60.0>}
``` 
Instead of ` (CaseClauseError) no case clause matching: <string>` would it be possible to match on name keyword being a string and throw a more helpful error message?
